chapter_title: PROCEDURES FOR AIR NAVIGATION SERVICES: AIRCRAFT OPERATIONS

questions.question_text: PANS-OPS means:
options: Pilots Alternate Navigational Systems and Operational Procedures
Procedures for Air Navigation Services - Aircraft operations
Procedures for Air Navigation Systems - Airfield operations

questions.question_text: The document that specifies the recommendations for instrument procedures is called...
Which of the following defines transition altitude?
options: The altitude above which the vertical position of an aircraft is determined by reference to local QHN
The altitude below which the vertical position of an aircraft is determined by reference to QNH
The altitude at which 1013 hPa is set and vertical position then reported as a flight level

questions.question_text: The Transition Level:
options: Is published for the aerodrome in the Section ENR of the AIP
Shall be the lowest flight level available for use above the transition altitude
Is calculated and declared for an approach by the Pilot-in command

questions.question_text: During flight through the transition layer the vertical position of the aircraft should be expressed as
options: Altitude above mean sea level during climb.
Either altitude above mean sea level or flight level during climb
Altitude above mean sea level during descent

questions.question_text: Transition from altitude to flight level, and vice-versa is done:
options: At transition level during climb and transition altitude during descent
At transition altitude during climb and transition level during descent

questions.question_text: Which of the following cruising levels would you select under the following conditions: True track $358^{\circ}$, variation $3^{\circ}$E, deviation $2^{\circ}$W?
In the vicinity of an aerodrome that is going to be used by the aircraft the vertical position of the aircraft shall be expressed in:
options: Altitude above sea level on or above the transition altitude
Flight level on or below the transition level
Altitude above sea level on or below the transition altitude

questions.question_text: The vertical position of an aircraft at or below the transition altitude will be reported:
The transition altitude of an aerodrome should not be below:
The pilot of a departing aircraft flying under IFR shall change the altimeter setting from QNH to standard setting 1013.25hPA when passing:
In the standard atmosphere FL150 is equivalent to:
A pre-flight altimeter check should be carried out:
options: At a known elevation on the aerodrome

questions.question_text: Which of the following correctly lists special purpose codes that are to be used in conjunction with Secondary Surveillance Radar (SSR)?
When acknowledging mode/code setting instructions, pilots shall:
options: Read back the mode and code to be set

questions.question_text: Pilots shall not operate the SSR special position indicator (IDENT) feature unless:
options: They operate a transponder with Mode C

questions.question_text: When the aircraft carries serviceable Mode C equipment, the pilot:
options: Shall continuously operate this mode only when the aircraft is within controlled airspace
Shall continuously operate this mode regardless of ATC instructions
Shall continuously operate this mode unless otherwise directed by ATC

questions.question_text: When an aircraft carries a serviceable transponder, the pilot shall operate the transponder:
options: At all times during flight, regardless of whether the aircraft is within or outside airspace where SSR is used for ATS purposes
Only when the aircraft is flying within controlled airspace
Only when the aircraft is flying within airspace where SSR is used for ATS purposes

questions.question_text: Your transponder code assigned by ATC is 5320. In flight, in case of radio communications failure, you will squawk code:
The pilot of an aircraft losing two-way communication shall set the transponder to Mode A Code:
When the aircraft carries serviceable Mode C transponder, the pilot shall continuously operate this mode:
During a pre-flight a SSR transponder is found to be inoperative and immediate repair is not possible:
options: A flight to the closest airport, where a repair can be made is allowed
A flight can not be made
It is necessary to specify this failure in the appropriate field of the flight plan

questions.question_text: When an aircraft is subjected to unlawful interference, the pilot-in-command shall indicate the situation by setting the transponder to:
On receipt of a TA, pilots shall:
options: Respond immediately by following the TA as indicated
Not manoeuvre their aircraft in response to traffic advisories (TAs) only
Notify the appropriate ATC unit of the TA

questions.question_text: Airborne collision avoidance system (ACAS) indications shall be used by pilots in:
options: Both B) and C) are correct.
The active search for, and visual acquisition of, conflicting traffic.

questions.question_text: What are the two main objective of altimeter setting?
options: To read height and barometric pressure
QNH to be set in the vicinity of the aerodrome and QFE en route
To provide adequate terrain clearance and vertical separation

questions.question_text: Which of the following correctly defines altitude?
options: Vertical position with reference to MSL
Vertical position with reference to aerodrome elevation
Vertical position with reference to touchdown

questions.question_text: Which of the following correctly defines height?
options: Vertical position with reference to MSL
Vertical position with reference to aerodrome elevation
Vertical position with reference to touchdown

questions.question_text: Which of the following correctly defines flight level?
options: Vertical position with reference to MSL
Vertical position with reference to aerodrome elevation
Vertical position with reference to the standard pressure level

questions.question_text: If the QNH is 991 Mb where is FL? (Assume 1 $Mb=30~ft)$
Which of the following is the location of FL?
options: The first flight level above the transition level
The level defined with reference to a QNH of 1013.25mb

questions.question_text: What is the relationship between IFR and VFR flight level?
options: For given mag track, the VFR level is the IFR level plus 500' if below FL290
IFR levels are flown on mag tracks from 000 to 179 an VFR levels from 180 to 359
VFR levels may be flown in VMC or IMC, but IFR levels must only be flown in IMC

questions.question_text: At what point in a flight is the QNH communicated to the pilot by ATC?
If you are flying outside an aerodrome traffic zone, what are you required to set on your altimeter sub scale ?
options: The lowest forecast pressure setting with respect to MSL for the area in which you are flying
The local QNH obtained from FIS or the nearest aerodrome

questions.question_text: If you are flying en route below the transition level but are well briefed with regard to safety altitude, from where would you get altimeter setting information whilst airborne?
options: You only need the departure aerodrome and destination aerodrome QNH and then interpolate the difference whilst en route
Ask the met man to forecast the QNH for the route before you take off
Ask the FIS controller for local aerodrome QNHs

questions.question_text: You are approaching an aerodrome to land and call the approach controller at 10nm from the edge of the ATZ. Your flight conditions are VMC and you are flying VFR. When would you expect to be advised to set the aerodrome QNH?
options: On initial contact the app controller will pass QNH and tell you what altitude to fly at
On clearance to enter the traffic pattern established for a visual join to land
When descending below the transition altitude

questions.question_text: You test your altimeter with aerodrome QNH set. What would a serviceable altimeter read?
options: The height of the aeroplane above the datum
The elevation of the position of the aeroplane plus the height of the altimeter static vent
The altitude of the aeroplane above the datum

questions.question_text:
In selecting a flight level for a flight, which of the following should be taken into consideration?
1. Adequate terrain clearance is ensured
2. ATC requirements (Danger Areas, restricted airspace etc.) are complied with
3. Minimum traffic separation is ensured
4. Adequate separation from VFR traffic is ensured (differential flight levels applied)
5. The appropriate flight level in accordance with the table of flight levels
6. The level chosen complies with the table of cruising levels
What is the minimum gradient for missed approach procedure?
You are entering a FIR where SSR is used from an area where SSR is not used. What would you squawk?
Your aircraft is subjected to unlawful interference (hi jacking). Without upsetting the man with the gun, what would you squawk?
options: Either $A/7700$ or A/7500 depending upon the situation

questions.question_text: What are you required to do if you become aware that your transponder has failed?
options: Try recycling the transponder and set 7777 to maximise the response

questions.question_text: Which of the following is an invalid squawk?
On a single SSR control box/selector system (ie no changeover switch), what is the correct procedure for changing squawk?
options: Squawk 'standby', then change the code; then squawk 'normal'.
Squawk 'off', then change the code; then Squawk 'normal'.
Only change one digit at a time

questions.question_text: What does the abbreviation ACAS mean?
What does the abbreviation OIS mean?
What does the abbreviation DER mean?
The MSA, which must be established around a navigation facility, is in general valid within a sector of:
What is defined as the portion of a flight in which the aircraft descends below 1000 ft above the relevant DH or MDH?
A radial is:
options: A magnetic bearing to or from a VOR station, depending on whether the aircraft is inbound or outbound to or from the VOR
A magnetic bearing to a VOR station
A magnetic bearing extending from a VOR station

questions.question_text: A circling approach is:
options: A flight manoeuvre to be performed only under radar vectoring
A visual flight manoeuvre keeping the runway in sight

questions.question_text: What is the meaning of MEHT?
OCH for a precision approach is defined as:
options: The lowest height above mean sea level of the relevant runway used in establishing compliance with appropriate obstacle clearance requirements
The lowest altitude above the aerodrome elevation used in establishing compliance with appropriate obstacle clearance requirements
The lowest height above the elevation of the relevant runway threshold, at which a missed approach must be initiated to ensure compliance with the appropriate obstacle clearance criteria

questions.question_text: The approach categories of aircraft are based upon:
options: 1.3 times the stalling speed in clean configuration at minimum certified landing mass
1.3 times the stalling speed in the landing configuration at minimum certified landing mass
1.3 times the stalling speed in the landing configuration at maximum certified landing mass

questions.question_text: Maximum permissible bank angle in a holding pattern is degrees:

The term used to describe the visual phase of flight after completing an instrument approach, to bring an aircraft into position for landing on runway which is not suitably located for straight-in approach, is:
In a straight departure, the initial departure track is of the alignment of the runway centreline within:
In an instrument departure procedure the minimum obstacle clearance at the departure end of runway equals:
We can distinguish two types of departure routes. During a straight departure the initial departure track is within:
options: $15^{\circ}$ of the alignment of the runway centreline
$10^{\circ}$ of the alignment of the runway centreline
$25^{\circ}$ of the alignment of the runway centreline

questions.question_text: If in an instrument departure procedure the track to be followed by the aeroplane is published, the pilot is expected:
options: To correct for known wind to remain within the protected airspace
To request from ATC different heading for wind correction
To ignore the wind and proceed on a heading equal to the track

questions.question_text: In general, which is the main factor that dictates the design of an instrument departure procedure?
During an omni-directional departure, what height are you required to climb to before turning onto the desired track?
The main factor that dictates in general the design of an Instrument departure procedure is:
SID terminates at:
options: the first fix of the en-route phase.
point 15 nms from DER on departure leg.
fix decided by the pilot before reaching TOC

questions.question_text: A public transport aircraft shall not take-off unless the following minima for the departure airfield are satisfactory:
Obstacle clearance for an ILS approach is based on the assumption that the pilot does not deviate from the centreline more than:
options: half scale deflection of the localizer indicator
full scale deflection of the localizer indicator
half scale deflection of the glidepath indicator and horizontal $35^{\circ}$ off the centreline

questions.question_text: Who establishes the OCA/H (Obstacle Clearance Altitude/Height) for an approach procedure?
If visual reference is lost while circling to land from an instrument approach, it is expected that the pilot will make an initial climbing turn towards the:
A circling approach is:
options: A visual flight manoeuvre keeping the runway in sight
A visual flight manoeuvre to be conducted only in IMC
A flight manoeuvre to be performed only under radar vectoring

questions.question_text: When the visual manoeuvring (circling) area has been established the obstacle clearance altitude/height (OCA/H) is determined:
options: Only for categories C, D and E aircraft
For each category of aircraft, and it may be different for each one of them
For all categories of aircraft, and it is the same for all of them

questions.question_text: On a non-precision approach a so-called "straight-in-approach" is considered acceptable, if the angle between the final approach track and the runway centreline is:
If contact is lost with the runway on the downwind leg of a circling manoeuvre, what actions should be taken?
options: Turn towards the inner marker for the runway in use, maintaining circling altitude
If you have other visual cues, continue with ground contact

questions.question_text: Minimum sector altitudes are determined by the inbound radial in relation to the IAF. These sectors are established for a distance from the IAF of:
A "precision approach" is a direct instrument approach...
options: using bearing, elevation and distance information
carried out by a crew of at least two pilots trained with a specific working method
using at least one source of bearing information and one source of elevation or distance information

questions.question_text: The term used to describe the visual phase of flight after completing an instrument approach, to bring an aircraft into position for landing on runway which is not suitably located for straight-in approach is:
In a precision approach (ILS), the final approach segment begins at the:
Under which conditions may an aircraft on a straight-in-VOR approach continue its descend below the OCA?
options: When the aircraft has the control tower in sight
When the aircraft is in visual contact with the ground and with the runway lights in sight
When the aircraft is in contact with the ground but not with the runway in sight yet

questions.question_text: A turn executed by the aircraft during the initial approach between the end of the outbound track and the beginning of the Intermediate or final approach track is a:

A manoeuvre in which a turn is made away from a designated track followed by a turn in the opposite direction to permit the aircraft to intercept and proceed along the reciprocal of the designated track is called a:

1 the pilot has the landing threshold in sight
2 visual reference has been established and can be maintained
3 the required obstacle clearance can be maintained and a landing can be made
The combination regrouping all the correct statements is:

In an approach procedure, a descent or climb conducted in a holding pattern is called:
Which are the phases of a missed approach procedure?
When determining the OCA for a precision approach, obstacle height is referenced to:
options: highest obstacle within 25 nm of aerodrome

questions.question_text: What is gradient for departure runway?
The ILS glide path is normally intercepted between:
The factors considered in the calculations of DA/DH are:
options: The OCA/H based on the highest obstacle in the final approach path only, plus a margin for height loss on any go around
The OCA/H based on the highest obstacle in the missed approach path only plus an allowance for height loss on any go around
The OCA/H based on the highest obstacle in the approach or missed approach paths including an allowance for aircraft speed and height loss on any go around, plus a margin for operational factors

questions.question_text: What is the obstacle clearance in the intermediate approach segment?
Who is establishing the aerodrome operational minima for instrument approaches?
options: The appropriate authority of the State of the aircraft operator
The appropriate authority of the State of the aerodrome

questions.question_text: What is the primary area during the intermediate section of an instrument approach?
options: $3/4$ of the total width of the airspace used to determine the minimum obstacle clearance for the approach
$1/2$ of the total width of the airspace used to determine the minimum obstacle clearance for the approach
10 NM either side of the approach path

questions.question_text: In relation to the three entry sectors, the entry into the holding pattern shall be according to:
Related to the three entry sectors in a holding pattern, there is a zone of flexibility on either side of the sectors boundaries of:
What is the outbound timing in a holding pattern above FL 140?

options: Rate of $3^{\circ}$/sec or at a bank angle of $25^{\circ}$, which ever requires the lesser bank
Rate of $3^{\circ}$/sec or at a bank angle of $20^{\circ}$, which ever requires the lesser bank

questions.question_text: In a standard holding pattern turns are made:
options: In a direction depending on the wind direction

What obstacle clearance is guaranteed at a range of 5 nm from the edge of the holding area?
An expected approach time is given:
options: When an aircraft is instructed to hold
Once an aircraft has been holding for 20 minutes
